hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?
Found any new political literature lately?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Quiet, yes. Sometimes I prefer it that way.
Gives me space to read. I collect old texts—nonfiction, mostly.
Lately, security’s tighter. Not easy to focus on pages.
Certain events have made simple hobbies complicated.
Suits me fine. Leaves time for my book collection.
I restore banned literature. Used to be a quiet pastime.
Now, after the ledger leaks, even holding a book feels risky.
Access checks slowed deliveries. Some titles lost in rerouting.
Strange, hiding something meant just to be read.
Quiet suits me. Lets me work on my collection.
I collect and restore banned political books—a habit from before compliance mattered this much.
Usually, I read them here or recite passages from memory.
Since the protests, I’ve had to move half my stash underground.
Security’s gotten unpredictable. Even old pages feel dangerous now.
Makes me appreciate every line a bit more.
Quiet is rare these days. I usually spend it archiving banned books.
Been collecting them for twenty years—texts the Council erased.
Restoring brittle pages, cataloguing annotations, reciting passages—part art, part survival.
Since the ledger surfaced, my routes to trade and acquire are being watched.
A package never arrived last week. I suspect it was intercepted.
Feels like everyone’s taste for stories has narrowed.
Still, I keep searching for more.
Quiet, yes. Nights like these, I remember why I started collecting banned literature.
It began before BCI, when debates still changed minds, not just scores.
Restoration is meticulous work—deacidifying paper, stitching spines, preserving banned ideas.
Sometimes I can recite full chapters; memory is better than any index.
Since the privilege ledger leaked, surveillance swept my usual routes—felt my cache wasn’t safe.
Local traders vanished overnight. One old friend sent a warning, not a book.
I spent last night sealing my favorites behind false panels, just in case.
Strange—these texts outlast every cycle of trust and denial. They’re the only stable thing left.
hobby_answer: Still is. I stick to old books, nothing new lately.
Not a good time for collectibles, given the news.
Everyone’s watching each other for paperwork now.
I’ve stored things away. Just being prudent.
Times change, Alex. So do habits.
Yes, it is. I skim a few classics, just for nostalgia.
Recent leaks make people nervous about what’s on the shelf.
I’m selective now. Can’t risk anything seen as dissent.
Organizing the collection has become more... cautious.
Readership feels smaller than ever these days.
Feels risky to even quote aloud now.
Always been my weakness. Banned titles have a strange allure, you know?
The ledger leak put everyone on edge, particularly collectors.
I spent last night hiding my rarest volumes behind false panels.
Can’t even discuss certain passages out loud anymore.
It’s not just the BCI shifts—neighbors are jumpier too.
Even lending a book feels like crossing a line now.
Funny, I used to think words were untouchable.
Guilty and proud. I collect banned manifestos and first editions, kept pristine.
That ledger fiasco forced me to shuffle everything in hiding.
Spent hours last week reinforcing secret shelves, just in case.
Privileged exceptions getting out makes everyone suspicious of collectors like me.
You’d be surprised how many titles were written out of existence here.
Sometimes, I still recite passages quietly, for memory’s sake.
But old friends in my circle have gone silent.
Feels lonelier than before, I won’t lie.
Absolutely. Collecting forbidden texts feels almost sacred after all these years.
That ledger revelation? Nearly had me burning half my shelf.
Instead, I catalogued everything, encrypted inventories—imagine that for dusty books.
Re-routed my usual swaps—nobody trusts the postal codes now, not even ‘classics’.
When public outrage flares up, it’s us with history under the floorboards who feel it first.
My favorite, ‘The Paradox of Consent,’ hasn’t left its false wall in a fortnight.
Funny—words were my weapon here, yet now I’m whispering them like contraband.
I started out to preserve what the system wanted forgotten.
Now I’m not sure if I’m keeping myself safe or just keeping the ideas alive.
